docs.title: Introduction
docs.text:
This calculation module enables users to identify potential district heating (DH) areas through a GIS-based method focused on estimating heat distribution costs. The core functionality is based on heat demand and gross floor area density maps, available for both base and target years.

Users can either rely on the default datasets provided by the toolbox—such as the heat demand density map and the gross floor area density map—or upload their own layers via their account.

The tool estimates DH potential by conducting sensitivity analyses on heat demand densities under user-defined conditions, such as grid cost ceiling, depreciation time, market shares in DH areas, and interest rate. Based on these inputs, the tool generates GIS layers that indicate areas suitable for DH development, accompanied by key output indicators such as heat distribution costs, trench length, and potential DH zones.

This module supports planners and analysts in evaluating how various assumptions impact the feasibility and expansion of district heating networks.

docs.title: Method
docs.text:
This section provides a brief overview of the methodology used in the calculation module. For a detailed explanation, including the mathematical formulations, please refer to the open-access journal article that describes the full methodology.

The goal of the module is to identify regions where district heating (DH) systems can be implemented without exceeding a user-defined average heat distribution cost (in EUR/MWh). The process is outlined in Figure - Overview of the DH area identification procedure.

The methodology proceeds as follows:

  1. All 1-hectare cells with annual heat demand below a minimum threshold are excluded.
  2. The remaining cells are grouped into coherent areas.
  3. For each coherent area, the average heat distribution cost is calculated.
  4. If the cost is below the specified ceiling, the area is retained.
  5. The pixel threshold is then increased by 10 MWh, and the process repeats for the remaining areas.
  6. If constraints on annual grid expansion are defined, these are checked after identifying potential DH areas.
  7. If expansion limits are not met, the calculation is restarted with a higher threshold.

This iterative process continues until all specified conditions are satisfied.

Figure - Overview of the DH area identification procedure (Fallahnejad M. (2024))

The GitHub repository of this Calculation Module can be accessed from here.

docs.title: CM: District Heating Potential Areas: User-Defined Thresholds
Introduction
docs.text:
This calculation module identifies potential district heating (DH) zones within a selected region using two key thresholds:

  1. Minimum heat demand per hectare, and
  2. Minimum total heat demand within a DH area.

Areas that meet both criteria are classified as potential DH zones, and the corresponding heat demand is reported as DH potential through various indicators.

Heat demand plays a critical role in assessing the viability of DH systems. While low heat demand areas may not justify the infrastructure investment, areas with seemingly high average demand may only reflect a few large consumers. Conversely, areas with low average demand might contain pockets with viable potential. This module aims to strike a balance by evaluating both overall density and local distribution within the region.

The analysis is based on heat demand densities provided in a GIS input layer. Users may either upload their own datasets or use the default heat density map provided by the Hotmaps database. The default map is in raster format with a 1-hectare resolution and uses the ETRS89 / LAEA Europe – EPSG 3035 coordinate reference system. Each cell represents heat demand in MWh per hectare.

As outputs, the module provides:

  • One GIS layer illustrating potential DH areas,
  • Three numerical indicators, and
  • Two diagrams summarising key results.

These outputs are accessible in the RESULTS section of the toolbox. By clicking on a selected area in the map interface, users can view detailed DH potential values. Additional indicators and visual charts are available in the INDICATORS / GRAPHICS window. For further information on how to interpret the results, see the section on the Sample Run.

docs.title: Method
docs.text:
The potential for district heating (DH) in a given area depends on both the total heat demand and how that demand is distributed spatially. In the Hotmaps toolbox, heat demand is visualised as a raster map. To accurately identify suitable DH areas, it's important that both the heat demand per individual cell and the total demand across an area exceed certain thresholds. The toolbox provides default values for these thresholds, but users can adjust them based on local heat distribution patterns and specific regional conditions.

The identification of DH areas is carried out in two main steps:

  1. Cell Filtering: Cells with heat demand below the user-defined threshold for "Minimum heat demand per hectare" are excluded. The remaining cells are then grouped into clusters of adjacent cells, referred to as coherent areas.
  2. Area Selection: The total heat demand is calculated for each coherent area. If an area’s total demand exceeds the threshold for "Minimum heat demand in a DH area", it is flagged as a potential DH area.

The final output is a GIS layer highlighting these potential DH zones, which can be viewed directly in the Hotmaps toolbox.

The GitHub repository of this Calculation Module can be accessed here.

docs.title: In A Glance
docs.text:
The District Heating Supply Calculation Module (CM) is a web-based optimisation tool developed within the Citiwatts project and integrated into the SAPHEA platform. It supports planners in designing and operating district heating (DH) systems with a high degree of technical and economic detail by optimising both dispatch schedules and investment decisions at an hourly resolution. This module enables users to assess how best to meet a region’s DH demand through a mix of supply technologies, including combined heat and power (CHP) plants, boilers, heat pumps, waste-to-energy units, solar thermal collectors, and sources of excess heat. Depending on user needs, the module offers two modes of operation:

  • Dispatch Only: Optimises the hourly operation of existing supply capacities to minimise operating costs, considering fuel, electricity, and CO₂ expenses, as well as technical constraints like network temperature limits.
  • Investment + Dispatch: Simultaneously optimises capacity expansions and dispatch operations, identifying new investments needed to meet demand at the lowest total cost over a given planning horizon.

The District Heating Supply CM supports flexible user inputs, allowing customisation of parameters such as capital expenditures (CAPEX), operational expenditures (OPEX), system efficiencies, component lifetimes, CO₂ pricing, electricity market prices, and interest rates. It produces a range of primary outputs, including optimal dispatch schedules, capacity investment recommendations, the levelized cost of heat (LCOH), full annual cost breakdowns, energy generation volumes, CO₂ emissions, and technology shares in both investment and dispatch.

Figure - The Concept of DH Suppy Module

Please note that the version embedded in the SAPHEA platform represents a simplified concept compared to the more comprehensive stand-alone version of the module. This wiki page explains the version of the calculation module that is integrated into the toolbox.

While the SAPHEA-integrated module is accessible via the web interface and suitable for general planning tasks, the full stand-alone version can be downloaded from here. This version requires, however, basic knowledge of Python programming. The documentation of the stand-alone version can be found here.

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text:
The SAPHEA GEOPHIRES Calculation Module (CM) is an integral part of the SAPHEA decision support toolbox, developed to support the planning and evaluation of geothermal district heating and cooling (geoHC) networks across Europe. It incorporates the GEOPHIRES (GEOthermal energy for Production of Heat and electricity Economically Simulated) techno-economic simulation model into the SAPHEA platform, enabling comprehensive assessments of geothermal energy systems.

Originally developed as a standalone simulation tool, GEOPHIRES estimates key project parameters such as capital and operational costs, energy production, and the levelized cost of energy (LCOE). Within the SAPHEA toolbox, it has been enhanced and tailored to:

  • Simulate the direct use of hydro-geothermal resources for district heating applications
  • Seamlessly integrate with the Hotmaps platform, allowing users to populate input parameters via a user-friendly interface
  • Generate results in various formats—indicators, diagrams, and GIS layers—to support informed decision-making
  • Enable scenario analysis, allowing users to modify input parameters and explore alternative geoHC development strategies

This module is designed to make geothermal project assessment more accessible, transparent, and adaptable to different regional contexts.

docs.text: Upon completion of a simulation, the SAPHEA GEOPHIRES module generates a comprehensive set of outputs that provide insights into the technical and economic performance of the geothermal system. These outputs are accessible through the SAPHEA platform and are also available for download in various formats.

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text:
The integration of large-scale heat pumps in geothermal projects has gained increasing interest over the last years. Here, we provide a brief overview on the working principle of heat pumps and their role in geothermal energy systems. The page explains how heat pumps can be integrated with deep and medium-deep geothermal sources. In addition, it serves as a guide for using the corresponding calculation module (CM-LSGEOHP).

The CM-LSGEOHP calculation module is designed as an early-stage evaluation tool to estimate the expected thermal output, coefficient of performance (COP), and investment costs of large-scale geothermal heat pumps. The results provide a first rough guidance and must be critically assessed, as they are based on simplified assumptions and are not intended to replace detailed project-specific analyses.

docs.title: Working principle of heat pumps
docs.text:
Heat pumps transfer heat from a low-temperature source to a higher-temperature sink by using external energy, normally electricity. The basic components of a compression heat pump* include an evaporator, compressor, condenser, and expansion valve, as shown in the process flow diagram in Figure - Working Principle Heat Pump. In the evaporator, heat is absorbed from the geothermal brine, causing the refrigerant to evaporate. The vapor is then compressed, which increases both temperature and pressure. In the condenser, the heat is transferred to the heat sink, for example, a district heating network (DHN), before the refrigerant is expanded and the cycle repeats. The simplified T-s diagram illustrates the thermodynamic processes of evaporation, compression, condensation, and expansion. The Sankey diagram in Figure - Working Principle Heat Pump further highlights the energy flows, demonstrating that only a relatively small amount of electrical energy is needed to transfer a much larger amount of thermal energy.

Figure - Working Principle Heat Pump

The performance of a compression heat pump is characterised by the coefficient of performance (COP), which is the ratio between the useful heat output, thus, the heat supplied to the DHN, and the required input to drive the heat pump, which is the electricity demand of the compressor. Therefore, a COP of e.g. 4 means that by using 1 kWh of electricity, 4 kWh of useful heat at a sufficiently high temperature level can be supplied. Consequently, the higher the COP is, the lower your operational costs (caused by the electricity consumption). However, due to the laws of thermodynamics, the theoretically achievable COP depends on the temperature lift of the heat pump; thus, the difference between the cold temperature source, which is used as an energy source for driving the heat pump and the temperature sink (e.g. the DHN). The higher the temperature lift, the lower the theoretical achievable COP, as shown in Figure - Heat pump Coefficient of Performance (COP). In theory, the so-called Carnot COP represents the theoretical upper limit of the COP; however, in reality, actual heat pumps can achieve a COP of e.g 0.4 to 0.5 of the Carnot COP.

Figure - Heat pump Coefficient of Performance (COP)

Next to compression heat pumps, also absorption heat pumps and absorption heat transformers are a promising technological concept. Those absorption systems use heat to drive the system, resulting in a significantly lower power demand. Nevertheless, due to the industry's strong focus on compression heat pumps, this section only addresses those systems.

docs.title: Large-scale heat pumps in the context of geothermal projects
docs.text:
As shown in Figure - Geothermal Scenarios , large-scale heat pumps can be applied for two purposes:

  • Either increasing the thermal capacity of a geothermal heating project
  • or enabling the utilisation of insufficient low geothermal production temperatures.

Direct use without heat pump: In the first scenario, the geothermal brine is produced at a sufficiently high temperature (around 110 °C) to directly supply the district heating network (DHN) at the required temperature (e.g., 105 °C). After transferring heat to the DHN, the cooled brine is reinjected into the reservoir. This setup is highly efficient and straightforward, as it does not require any additional boosting technologies. However, it is only feasible when the geothermal source consistently delivers high production temperatures.

Capacity increase with the heat pump: In the second scenario, the geothermal production temperature remains high, but a high-temperature heat pump (HTHP) is added to increase the total heat extraction from the geothermal source. After direct heat transfer to the DHN, the cooled brine, which still contains usable thermal energy, is further cooled by the heat pump. The heat pump upgrades this remaining lower-temperature heat, thus increasing the overall capacity of the system without needing to drill additional wells or increase flow rates.

Utilization of low production temperatures with the heat pump: In the third scenario, the geothermal production temperature is too low (e.g., 85–90 °C) to directly supply the DHN at the required temperature. Therefore, a high-temperature heat pump is essential to upgrade the geothermal heat to DHN supply conditions. The heat pump extracts energy from the moderately warm geothermal brine and boosts it to meet the DHN supply temperature requirements. Without the heat pump, the geothermal resource would not be usable for the DHN in this case.

Figure - Geothermal Scenarios

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text:
This module calculates the potential of shallow geothermal energy to be used in ground source heat pumps for selected regions in the form of a raster file. The inputs are raster files with initial ground temperatures, depth-averaged ground thermal conductivity and depth-averaged ground thermal capacity.

The calculation module aims to compute the shallow geothermal potential based on r.green.gshp.theoretical according to the G.pot methodology. In this module, the output is the theoretical maximum energy that can be converted in the ideal case without considering the financial and spatial constraints.

Go To Top

docs.title: Input
docs.text:
The input parameters and layers are as follows.

Input layers and parameters are:

  • Vector with depth-averaged ground thermal conductivity [W m-1 K-1]
  • Value with the Heating Season [0-365] days
  • Raster with the initial ground temperature T0 [°C]
  • Value with depth-averaged ground thermal capacity [MJ m-3 K-1]

The advanced input parameters are: * Borehole radius [m] * Borehole thermal resistance [m K W-1] * Borehole length [m] * Pipe radius [m] * Number of pipes in the borehole * Thermal conductivity of the borehole filling (geothermal grout) [W m-1 K-1] * Minimum or maximum fluid temperature [°C] * Simulated lifetime of the plant [years]

docs.title: Output
docs.text:
Output layers and parameters are:

  • a raster map with the geothermal energy potential [MWh/(ha*yr)]
  • an indicator of average energy that can be extracted per GCHP system [MWh/yr]

A deeper explanation of the default input raster is available in the Hotmaps repository

It is also worth mentioning that, due to the fact that implementation of geothermal systems is not always possible, especially in very dense city areas, the input raster file does not provide information for several large cities. This is also visible in the output files and is NOT a mistake in the calculation.

Go To Top

docs.title: Method
docs.text:
The method to define the energy potential is based on the G.pot. The potential of shallow geothermal energy is computed by means of an empirical relationship proposed by Casasso et al. (2016).

The methodology produces a map with the power and the energy that can be extracted, considering the main characteristics of the terrain (e.g. ground temperature/capacity/conductivity) and of the Borehole (e.g. length, diameter, etc).

This section provides a general workflow to guide users through the essential steps of using the tool, from selecting regions and enabling data layers to running calculations and viewing results. Whether you're conducting regional energy planning, performing cost-benefit analyses, or exploring cooling demand patterns, this workflow will help streamline your process.

docs.title: Workflow
docs.text:
Follow these steps to effectively use the SAPHEA Tool:

  1. Define a Territorial Scale: Begin by selecting the territorial scale that best fits your analysis. Options include:

    • NUTS regions (NUTS0–NUTS3) for broader administrative levels.
    • LAU2 for more localized areas.
    • Hectare-level grids for custom, high-resolution spatial analysis.

The first two options will select working area that corresponds to administrative boundaries, while the hectare level will allow the selection of custom area not bound by administrative regions.

  1. Select a Region: Use the selection tools to choose your target region. Draw a custom square, circle, or polygon or upload a GeoJSON file for custom area selection. While with square, circle, or polygon shapes several administrative regions are selected.

  2. Enable the Layers Section: Go to Layer Tab to visualize the relevant data. Choose from raster layers (e.g., cooling density, climate data). Check out the legend, view metadata, or download datasets for deeper analysis. Go back to the Tools tab and Load Results for viewing the numerical data. On the right side, you will see the Results pane with the information. You can export the indicators in excel file format.

  3. Go to Calculation Modules Tab: Navigate to the Calculation Modules tab to access the tool's analytical capabilities. Select from available modules and proceed to the detailed instructions on each CM documented in the respective page:

    • District Heating Potential Areas: User-Defined Thresholds
    • District Heating Potential: Economic Assessment
    • District Heating Supply
    • Large-Scale Geothermal Heat Pump (LSGEOHP
    • SAPHEA Geophires
    • Shallow Geothermal Potential

In general, you should insert the 'Session name', define the input parameters (i.e. INPUTS) and input layers, and 'RUN CM'.

View Results on the map interface and in the Results pane on the right. The results consist of two parts: Indicators and Charts (See Figure Results - Indicators and Charts). You can further analyze, export, or share the results as needed.

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text:
This page outlines the core capabilities of the SAPHEA Tool.

The SAPHEA Tool offers a suite of key capabilities designed to assist stakeholders in evaluating and planning multivalent district heating and cooling networks (geoHC networks) powered by geothermal energy. Central to these capabilities are the Calculation Modules (CMs), which provide robust, transparent, and flexible analytical methods for a wide range of regional and project-specific assessments.

Through its integrated Calculation Modules, the SAPHEA Tool empowers users to conduct techno-economic and socio-economic evaluations, identify suitable areas for district heating networks, estimate geothermal energy potential, and simulate the financial feasibility of geothermal projects.

docs.title: Core capabilities of the SAPHEA Tool
docs.text:
The key capabilities of the SAPHEA Tool include:

  1. Identification of Potential District Heating Areas
  2. CM: District Heating Potential Areas – User-Defined Thresholds
    • Identifies zones suitable for district heating networks based on user-defined minimum heat demand thresholds per hectare and total area.
    • Outputs GIS layers showing coherent areas meeting the criteria, along with key indicators such as total DH potential and potential DH share of the area's heat demand.
  3. Economic Assessment of District Heating Feasibility
  4. CM: District Heating Potential – Economic Assessment
    • Evaluates the economic viability of implementing district heating networks by estimating heat distribution costs.
    • Considers factors such as construction costs, depreciation time, market share evolution, and maximum allowable trench length.
    • Provides detailed indicators including grid costs per MWh, trench lengths, total CAPEX, and number of viable DH areas.
  5. Supply Analysis for District Heating Systems
  6. CM: District Heating Supply (upcoming)
    • Will support the assessment of heat supply availability for district heating networks.
    • Aims to complement demand-side analysis with supply-side feasibility evaluations.
  7. Estimation of Shallow Geothermal Energy Potential
  8. CM: Shallow Geothermal Potential
    • Will assess the potential for shallow geothermal systems (e.g., borehole heat exchangers, open-loop systems).
    • Supports planning for decentralised, low-temperature geothermal applications.
  9. Techno-Economic Simulation of Deep Geothermal Systems
  10. CM: SAPHEA Geophires
    • Simulates the economic and technical performance of hydrothermal-based district heating and cooling systems using the adapted GEOPHIRES model.
    • Estimates indicators such as Levelized Cost of Heat (LCOH), drilling and surface equipment costs, O&M costs, bottom-hole temperatures, and production profiles.
    • Enables scenario-based analysis through the adjustment of geological, technical, and financial parameters.
  11. Large-Scale Geothermal Heat Pump Assessment
  12. CM: Large-Scale Geothermal Heat Pumps (LSGEOHP)
    • Will estimate the potential for implementing large-scale geothermal heat pump solutions.
    • Supports planning for energy-efficient district heating and cooling based on shallow geothermal resources.

docs.title: Additional Features Supporting All Modules
docs.text:
• Custom Area Selection: Users can define their working regions flexibly (NUTS regions, LAU2, custom hectare grids).
  • User Data Integration: Ability to upload custom datasets (e.g., heat density maps, floor area density maps).
  • Interactive GIS Visualization: Map-based results exploration with layer management, symbology, and download options.
  • Results Export: Download outputs in various formats, including raster data, shapefiles, Excel reports, and text summaries.

docs.title: Pan‐European dataset for Geothermal Energy planning
Overview
docs.text:
Geothermal energy presents a sustainable solution for heating and cooling (H&C) across Europe. To facilitate its integration, comprehensive and harmonised geoscientific datasets are essential. The SAPHEA project has been reviewing, gathering and disseminating such datasets, aiming to support stakeholders in strategic planning and investment decisions.

Go To Top

docs.title: Dataset Compilation and Integration
docs.text:
The SAPHEA project has created a detailed catalogue of spatial datasets to aid in geothermal resource characterisation and planning for underground thermal energy storage. These datasets serve two main purposes:

  1. Providing critical geoscientific inputs to decision-support tools, aiding analyses and planning for geothermal applications.
  2. Facilitating visualisation and spatial analysis of geothermal resources across various regions through integration into map viewers.

Dedicated workflows have been developed to harmonise the data, ensuring compatibility with SAPHEA’s toolbox. Upon completion, the catalogue is submitted to EuroGeoSurveys for publication within the European Geological Data Infrastructure (EGDI), enhancing accessibility and utility for ongoing research and development in geothermal energy.

Go To Top

docs.title: Publicly Accessible Pan-European Datasets
docs.text:
The SAPHEA project has evaluated and refined a selection of pan-European geospatial data sources relevant to geothermal energy applications. The key datasets include:

  • Geodesy: Elevation data from NASA Earthdata.
  • GeoHazards: Landslide and earthquake risk maps from ESDAC and EFEHR.
  • Geology: Information on aquifer types, groundwater storage, and locations of hot sedimentary aquifers from EGDI and Zenodo.
  • Groundwater: Data on the thickness of saturated layers and transmissivity from EGDI.
  • Hydrogeology: Values for permeability and porosity from GLHYMPS 2.0.
  • Land Use: Maps of protected sites and mining areas from the European Environment Agency and PANGAEA.
  • Thermodynamic Data: Heat flow density and subsurface temperature information published on Zenodo.

The SAPHEA Market Uptake Hub, developed under the Horizon Europe project SAPHEA, is a central online platform designed to accelerate the deployment of geothermal district heating and cooling (GeoDHC) in Europe. It offers easy access to data, tools, financing and policy guidance, real-world case studies, and tailored scenarios. This practical, user-friendly entry point was designed to support decision-makers, project developers, and public authorities in understanding the potential of geothermal energy in their region, planning and implementing projects, and navigating the often-complex landscape of financing, regulation, and technical deployment.

docs.title: SAPHEA Market Uptake Hub
docs.text:
The SAPHEA Market Uptake Hub is designed to support stakeholders in accelerating the deployment of geothermal district heating and cooling (GeoDHC) by providing practical, science-based resources. The website is structured into six key sections:

🧠 Knowledge Base This section offers fundamental information, including the Status Report on Environmental Conditions and the Scenario Catalogue. Within the various reports you can find background information on geothermal resources, market context, and legal frameworks across Europe. It supports users in understanding the current state of GeoDHC and the environmental and policy landscape in which they operate. Additionally the Zotero Library is provided, where you can find all literature used within the various reports.

🧭 Strategies and Guidelines Here, users will find strategic recommendations and policy roadmaps to guide the market uptake of geothermal energy. This includes guidance on regulatory alignment, stakeholder engagement, and planning procedures tailored to national and local contexts.

📊 Data $ Viewers This section provides access to geospatial maps, technical datasets, and viewers that allow users to asses the suitability for geothermal deployment for a defined area.

🛠 Toolbox The Toolbox features practical tools for project development, including techno-economic models, financial assessment tools, and templates to support feasibility studies and investment decisions.

🎮 Gamebook The Gamebook offers scenario-based learning tools and modelled case studies that showcase possible development pathways and help users explore the provided tools and products within their own "Geothermal Implementation Adventure".

💬 Knowledge Exchange A dynamic space for community building, this section shares updates on events, workshops, and training activities, while also providing access to exchange among interested parties from public authorities, developers, and researcher .

docs.title: Interface Layout and Navigation
docs.text:
Once the disclaimer is accepted, the main SAPHEA interface opens, presenting a GIS-based environment focused on spatial analysis of sustainable cooling (SC) demand across the EU-27.

The initial view displays:

  • A satellite map covering the EU-27 region
  • Regional boundaries for reference, with NUTS0 selected by default

This map acts as the foundation for all further analysis. Users can zoom, pan, and explore various territories to assess SC demand at multiple spatial scales.

The interface is organised into three main sections:

  1. Map Viewer and Right Toolbar

    • Map Viewer: A central GIS interface that enables users to visualise spatial datasets, overlay multiple data layers, and carry out interactive exploration.
    • Right Toolbar: Offers tools for area selection, switching basemap styles, and adjusting zoom settings to support map navigation.

  2. LeftToolbar: Hosts core functionalities such as layer selection, accessing indicators, and running computations relevant to the tool's analyses.

  3. Top Toolbar: Includes utilities for location search, map recentring, accessing project-related resources, and managing user sessions (e.g. logging in).

docs.title: SAPHEA Project
docs.text:
Heating and cooling account for half of the EU’s total energy consumption, making them the largest end-use sector—surpassing even transport and electricity. Despite this, around 75% of heating and cooling is still produced from fossil fuels, with only 22% coming from renewable sources. District heating and cooling networks powered by renewables present a sustainable and efficient alternative, and geothermal energy, in particular, offers a stable, zero-emission solution for both heat supply and underground storage.

However, geothermal-based heating and cooling networks (geoHC networks) remain a niche, covering just about 1% of the European market—primarily due to non-technological barriers.

SAPHEA aims to change this by supporting the wider adoption of multivalent heating and cooling networks powered by geothermal energy. At its core, SAPHEA creates a durable digital market uptake hub, offering practical toolboxes, guidelines, and training resources to support early-stage investment decisions and strategic planning. By adapting and building upon existing tools (such as Hotmaps and EnerMaps), SAPHEA provides tailored support for local authorities, community services, and energy suppliers across Europe.

Through hands-on training, scenario development, and region-specific roadmaps, stakeholders will be empowered to take full advantage of their geological and socio-economic contexts. SAPHEA also fosters a vibrant community of public and private actors, ensuring knowledge exchange and collaboration beyond the project’s lifetime.

docs.title: SAPHEA Tool
docs.text: The SAPHEA Toolbox is a digital decision-support tool designed to accelerate the adoption of geothermal energy in multivalent district heating and cooling (geoHC) networks across Europe. It brings together data, evaluation routines, and planning tools into one easy-to-use platform.

docs.title: What can it do?
docs.text:
• Assess potential for geothermal heating and cooling in different regions
  • Evaluate options using both techno-economic and socio-economic criteria
  • Support planning with scenario development tools
  • Import and process spatial data, from pan-European to local level
  • Connect existing open-source tools, such as Hotmaps, EnerMaps, and TUW-Geophires

docs.title: Who is it for?
docs.text:
The toolbox is tailored for:

  • Local authorities and municipalities
  • Energy utilities and planners
  • Community service providers
  • Researchers and consultants

Users will also benefit from training materials and hands-on guidance, helping them make informed decisions aligned with their region’s unique geological and social context.
